comments.body_markdown: According to [SpringApplication#run](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/blob/148c632299f408a50ba506b1ec79a9938730d3b6/spring-boot-project/spring-boot/src/main/java/org/springframework/boot/SpringApplication.java#L317) spring-boot fires those beans after context has been refreshed, so, yes, it is safe to use this feature.
comments.body: According to SpringApplication#run spring-boot fires those beans after context has been refreshed, so, yes, it is safe to use this feature.

answers.body_markdown:
There are different ways to run code after spring boot application startup.

 - CommandLineRunner interface (with command-line arguments as string array)
 - ApplicationRunner interface (with ApplicationArguments instead of string array)
 - ApplicationStartedEvent - triggered after context has been refreshed but before command-line and application runners are called
 - ApplicationReadyEvent - triggered after any application and command-line runners are called

You can even combine multiple options. They will execute in following order:

 1. ApplicationStartedEvent
 2. ApplicationRunner or CommandLineRunner depends on @Order
 3. ApplicationReadyEvent

[Source: [https://stacktraceguru.com/springboot/run-method-on-startup][1]]


  [1]: https://stacktraceguru.com/springboot/run-method-on-startup
answers.title: Does Spring Boot ApplicationRunner.run() run when all beans are created?
answers.body:
There are different ways to run code after spring boot application startup.

  • CommandLineRunner interface (with command-line arguments as string array)
  • ApplicationRunner interface (with ApplicationArguments instead of string array)
  • ApplicationStartedEvent - triggered after context has been refreshed but before command-line and application runners are called
  • ApplicationReadyEvent - triggered after any application and command-line runners are called

You can even combine multiple options. They will execute in following order:

  1. ApplicationStartedEvent
  2. ApplicationRunner or CommandLineRunner depends on @Order
  3. ApplicationReadyEvent

[Source: https://stacktraceguru.com/springboot/run-method-on-startup]

items.title: Does Spring Boot ApplicationRunner.run() run when all beans are created?
items.body:
Question: does spring-boot function ApplicationRunner.run() run when all beans are created or does it run when the bean which implements the interface is built?

For example, given:

@Component
public class MyRunner implements ApplicationRunner {
    @Override
    public void run(ApplicationArguments args) throws Exception {
       // run some logic...
    }
}

@Component 
pubic class OtherClass{
  // ...
}

Does MyRunner.run()

  • run when both the MyRunner bean and the OtherClass bean are created, or

  • run when just the MyRunner bean is created and the

    OtherClass bean is not created?

I think the latter is the case based on https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/api/org/springframework/boot/ApplicationRunner.html

public interface ApplicationRunner

Interface used to indicate that a bean should run when it is contained within a SpringApplication. Multiple ApplicationRunner beans can be defined within the same application context and can be ordered using the Ordered interface or @Order annotation.

Why asking the question? I am considering to run some logic when my spring-boot application starts. I know both ApplicationRunner and ApplicationListener<ContextRefreshedEvent> can be used for that purpose but do not know which one is better. If ApplicationRunner.run() may run while some beans are not created, it will be not reliable for my use case.

items.title: How to implement reactive health indicator having health information from multiple webclients?
items.body:
I am trying to implement reactive health indicator to check health of multiple target services.

However , respective services are json is not getting parsed. I understood that's Mono of Health is having Mono of Map. To remove Mono of Map , if I use block() then also it fails with error as block() is not allowed in reactive call. I tried to use map() function and populate value in another map but no value is being passed to that map and it's not subscribed by caller. Since I am using spring boot actuator I cannot force caller to subscribe so how can I achieve below response in health check

Desired Response

> "reactiveTarget": {
>             "status": "UP"            {
>               "target1": {
>                   "status": "UP"
>               },
>               "target2": {
>                   "status": "UP"
>               }           }
>         },

Achieved Response

"reactiveTarget": {
            "status": "UP",
            "details": {
                "target1": {
                    "scanAvailable": true
                },
                "holdingsWebClient": {
                    "target2": true
                }
            }
        },

Code used

@Component
@Slf4j
public class ReactiveTargetHealthIndicator implements ReactiveHealthIndicator {

    private final ApplicationContext context;

    private String overallStatus="UP";

    public ReactiveTargetHealthIndicator(@NonNull ApplicationContext context) {
        this.context = context;
    }

    @Override
    public Mono<Health> health() {
        return checkTargetServiceHealth().onErrorResume(
                ex -> Mono.just(new Health.Builder().down(ex).build())
        );
    }

    private Mono<Health> checkTargetServiceHealth() {
        var target = this.context;
        Map<String, Mono<Map<String, String>>> targetServiceBeans= new LinkedHashMap<>();
        while (target != null) {
            target.getBeansOfType(WebClient.class)
                    .forEach((name, webclient) -> targetServiceBeans.put(name, createReport(name,webclient)));
            target = target.getParent();
        }
        log.info("Reactive Webclient Beans [{}]", targetServiceBeans); // Bean is empty
        var heathBuilder = new Health.Builder().withDetails(targetServiceBeans);
        return (overallStatus.equals("DOWN") )? Mono.just(heathBuilder.down().build())
                : Mono.just(heathBuilder.up().build());
    }

    private Mono<Map<String, String>> createReport(String name, WebClient webclient) {
        log.info("Reactive Webclient [{}] is triggered", name); // Here name of bean is coming
        return webclient.get()
                .uri("/actuator/health/liveness")
                .accept(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
                .retrieve()
                .bodyToMono(new ParameterizedTypeReference<Map<String, String>>() {
                })
                .onErrorResume(e -> {
                    log.error("Could not retrieve reactive health status of : {}", name, e);
                    overallStatus="DOWN";
                    return Mono.just(Map.of("status", "DOWN"));
                });
    }
}

answers.body_markdown:
If you want to create table from the Hibernate, you should pass hibernate properties in application.properties files.

    spring.datasource.url=jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/local
    spring.datasource.username=root
    spring.datasource.password=welcome
    spring.jpa.database=MYSQL
    spring.jpa.database-platform=org.hibernate.dialect.MySQLDialect
    spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=update
    spring.jpa.show-sql=true
    spring.flyway.validate-on-migrate=false

1) If you want create new table from entity you defined you can use create property of spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto
   e.g spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=create

2) For updating/alter table use update 
   e.g spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=update
    
3) For validating all tables are created use 
  e.g spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=validate

4) If you want to create and drop tables on application start up
  e.g spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=create-drop

answers.title: I need to print 5 ducks Horizontally, but nothing works
answers.body:
Same line length

When printing the ducks, every line must have the same length, currently some lines are longer than others.

Also note that lines using escape characters will need to appear longer in your editor!

Furthermore would it be practical to store all lines in an array and loop over that array, so that you don't need a for loop for every line!

Something like:

import java.util.ArrayList; 
public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int numDucks = 5;

        ArrayList<String> lines = new ArrayList<String>();
        lines.add("               ____           ");
        lines.add("            __|____|__        ");
        lines.add("           |__________|       ");
        lines.add("            ((      ))        ");
        lines.add("           ((     O  ```)\"    ");
        lines.add("           ((        ``)      ");
        lines.add("            \\\\     x``        ");
        lines.add("     (())    \\\\     X         ");
        lines.add("    ((  ))~~~~      ))        ");
        lines.add("  ((                 ))       ");
        lines.add(" ((      ~~~~~~       ))      ");
        lines.add(" ((     ~~~~~~~~      ))      ");
        lines.add("  \\\\     ~~~~~~      //       ");
        lines.add("   --__--__--__--__--__       ");
        lines.add("  --__--__--__--__--__        ");

        for (int i = 0; i < lines.size(); i++) { // for each line
            for (int j = 0; j < numDucks; j++) { // print it numDucks times
                System.out.print(lines.get(i));
            }
            System.out.println();
        }

    }
}

answers.body_markdown:
The [Answer by Cosemuckel][1] is correct. I can add some possible improvements.

# Soft-code each line-length

Firstly, the `ArrayList` could more compactly be replaced by [List.of][3]. 

Or even better, use [text blocks][4] for the duck. However the backslash characters must still be escaped. So I would “draw” my [ascii-art][5] in a simple [text-editor][6] like [*TextEdit*][7] on macOS. Then paste into the Java editor of a smart [IDE][8] like [IntelliJ][9] to create the text block while automatically adding escapes.

```java
final String duck =
        """
                      ____
                   __|____|__
                  |__________|
                   ((      ))
                  ((     O  ```)
                  ((        ``)
                   \\\\     x``
            (())    \\\\     X
           ((  ))~~~~      ))
         ((                 ))
        ((      ~~~~~~       ))
        ((     ~~~~~~~~      ))
         \\\\     ~~~~~~      //
          --__--__--__--__--__
         --__--__--__--__--__
        """;
```

To get lines from our duck string, use a [`Stream`][10] of the lines collected into a `List`.

The main concept I suggest here is to **👉 [soft-code][11] the line length**. Let your code determine the longest line. Then, when printing the other lines, add a number of spaces to match that line length. You can multiply the SPACE character with a call to [`String#repeat`][12]. Let the computer do the work!

We can replace the outer `for` loop with the simpler for-each syntax.

And we can better name our variables to be more [self-documenting][13].

Lastly, account for a gap between each duck horizontally.

This code makes use of streams and method references, advanced features of Java. But those can be replaced with conventional loops and method calls, for those who are not yet familiar.

```java
final int countDucks = 5;
final List < String > lines = duck.lines().toList();
final OptionalInt maxLength = lines.stream().mapToInt( String :: length ).max();
final int gap = 7;

answers.title: I need to print 5 ducks Horizontally, but nothing works
answers.body:
The Answer by Cosemuckel is correct. I can add some possible improvements.

Soft-code each line-length

Firstly, the ArrayList could more compactly be replaced by List.of.

Or even better, use text blocks for the duck. However the backslash characters must still be escaped. So I would “draw” my ascii-art in a simple text-editor like TextEdit on macOS. Then paste into the Java editor of a smart IDE like IntelliJ to create the text block while automatically adding escapes.

final String duck =
        """
                      ____
                   __|____|__
                  |__________|
                   ((      ))
                  ((     O  ```)
                  ((        ``)
                   \\\\     x``
            (())    \\\\     X
           ((  ))~~~~      ))
         ((                 ))
        ((      ~~~~~~       ))
        ((     ~~~~~~~~      ))
         \\\\     ~~~~~~      //
          --__--__--__--__--__
         --__--__--__--__--__
        """;

To get lines from our duck string, use a Stream of the lines collected into a List.

The main concept I suggest here is to 👉 soft-code the line length. Let your code determine the longest line. Then, when printing the other lines, add a number of spaces to match that line length. You can multiply the SPACE character with a call to String#repeat. Let the computer do the work!

We can replace the outer for loop with the simpler for-each syntax.

And we can better name our variables to be more self-documenting.

Lastly, account for a gap between each duck horizontally.

This code makes use of streams and method references, advanced features of Java. But those can be replaced with conventional loops and method calls, for those who are not yet familiar.

final int countDucks = 5;
final List < String > lines = duck.lines().toList();
final OptionalInt maxLength = lines.stream().mapToInt( String :: length ).max();
final int gap = 7;
if ( maxLength.isPresent() )
{
    for ( String line : lines )
    {
        for ( int duckIndex = 0 ; duckIndex < countDucks ; duckIndex++ )
        {
            System.out.print( line + " ".repeat( maxLength.getAsInt() - line.length() + gap ) );
        }
        System.out.println();
    }
}

When run.

comments.body_markdown: I'd expect a ThreadLocal only to be valid for a single execution of any message processing, then wiped - in other words: If you use ThreadPools, don't rely on persistent ThreadLocals. If you want those, don't use pools. If you make sure that a message is only processed by a single thread, you often don't even need locking, syncing etc., so I don't understand where your issue is (apart from the arbitrary decision to look for the same thread over and over. Don't do that)

They will be processed after 1000 messages collected, or after 5 seconds - the first from both. I'm using this method in order to do bulk update in the DB.. I have millions of users sending messages constantly. Would not want to update the DB every single message. Once the messages are processed and well processed, I'm removing them from the original Queue. If something bad happend, then they will be back in the queue after 30 seconds automatically and will be re-fetched.

comments.body_markdown: Don't use `ThreadLocal`. ThreadLocal only makes sense if it's a `static` variable, and you should get out of the habit of using static variables. Code with static variables is hard to maintain, and hard to test. Also, try to avoid writing code that has to be called by a certain thread. If a thing needs to be done, it should be OK for any thread to do it.
comments.body: Don't use ThreadLocal. ThreadLocal only makes sense if it's a static variable, and you should get out of the habit of using static variables. Code with static variables is hard to maintain, and hard to test. Also, try to avoid writing code that has to be called by a certain thread. If a thing needs to be done, it should be OK for any thread to do it.

comments.body_markdown: P.S., the reason why `ThreadLocal` even exists is because if you have old, single-threaded library code that has a lot of `static` variables, then making them `ThreadLocal` can be a shortcut to making a "thread-safe" version of it.
comments.body: P.S., the reason why ThreadLocal even exists is because if you have old, single-threaded library code that has a lot of static variables, then making them ThreadLocal can be a shortcut to making a "thread-safe" version of it.

comments.body_markdown: One thing that came to mind is that you can use Spring Batch to read x messages and do the commit (and have proper error handling). It has readers for jms, kafka etc. and you can set the chunk size. You would have a long live job. Another option is to manually do tx management and count the number of messages processed and then do a commit. Although I would first make it work with single messages and actually see if it is really a performance issue before optimizing.

items.body_markdown:
I have a messages queue, and thread pool.
Massive messages amount are being sent to queue.

In my threads (from the pool) I'm taking each message and pushing into the thread in-memory list using `ThreadLocal<List<...>>`.

My goal is on the X message to do some processing such as save to the DB,...

But,
I want as well, every Y seconds to do the same processing.

So, or we reached to X messages or Y seconds passed - then do processing.

What I've done is to start the timer on the first message and on fired to do the processing. The processing will stop the timer incase it was done by X messages.

My problem is with my timer that I create in the thread. The callback function naturally is being raised in a new thread and I don't have access to `ThreadLocal-List`.

I'm trying to avoid locking, syncing, and such - this is why i use ThreadLocal for my lists and timers.

Is there any elegant way to do what I wished for?

Maybe in the callback of my timer to execute the processing method with the same thread from the thread pool who created the timer?

--EDIT--
We use AWS SQS for the queue.
We fetch the message using SQSListener of spring cloud.
Our processing is basically saving to the DB.
We run on many pods (Kubernetes).

2 issues we faced:

1. Performing a simple Update on the DB every message in each thread of the `SQSListener` in each pod will be inefficient, therefor we thought about doing a bulk update which is faster - we tested it.

2. `SQSListener` creates max 10 threads to fetch the messages. It won't fetch another message till the thread is done. Therefor we wanted to "kicK" the message to a new thread fast, so `SQSListener` thread will fetch a new one and we would be able to collect more message for the bulk update.
items.title: How to execute function in a specific thread from threadpool
items.body:
I have a messages queue, and thread pool. Massive messages amount are being sent to queue.

In my threads (from the pool) I'm taking each message and pushing into the thread in-memory list using ThreadLocal<List<...>>.

My goal is on the X message to do some processing such as save to the DB,...

But, I want as well, every Y seconds to do the same processing.

So, or we reached to X messages or Y seconds passed - then do processing.

What I've done is to start the timer on the first message and on fired to do the processing. The processing will stop the timer incase it was done by X messages.

My problem is with my timer that I create in the thread. The callback function naturally is being raised in a new thread and I don't have access to ThreadLocal-List.

I'm trying to avoid locking, syncing, and such - this is why i use ThreadLocal for my lists and timers.

Is there any elegant way to do what I wished for?

Maybe in the callback of my timer to execute the processing method with the same thread from the thread pool who created the timer?

--EDIT-- We use AWS SQS for the queue. We fetch the message using SQSListener of spring cloud. Our processing is basically saving to the DB. We run on many pods (Kubernetes).

2 issues we faced:

  1. Performing a simple Update on the DB every message in each thread of the SQSListener in each pod will be inefficient, therefor we thought about doing a bulk update which is faster - we tested it.

  2. SQSListener creates max 10 threads to fetch the messages. It won't fetch another message till the thread is done. Therefor we wanted to "kicK" the message to a new thread fast, so SQSListener thread will fetch a new one and we would be able to collect more message for the bulk update.

answers.body_markdown:
If you desire to access the *module content* you should [`open`](http://download.java.net/java/jdk9/docs/api/java/lang/module/ModuleReference.html#open--) the `ModuleReference` that you've attained.
This would provide you access to the [`ModuleReader`](http://download.java.net/java/jdk9/docs/api/java/lang/module/ModuleReader.html) which

>  is intended for cases where access to the  resources in a module is
> required

> A resource in a module is identified by an abstract name that is a
> `'/'`-separated path string. For example, module `java.base` 
> may have a resource `"java/lang/Object.class"` that, by convention, 
> is the class file for `java.lang.Object`. A module reader may treat
> directories in the module content as resources (whether it does or not is
> module reader specific). Where the module content contains a directory
> that can be located as a resource then its name ends with a slash (`'/'`). The directory can also be located with a name that drops the trailing slash.



Do keep in mind though, that the docs also specify :

> A ModuleReader is open upon creation and is closed by invoking the
> [`close`](http://download.java.net/java/jdk9/docs/api/java/lang/module/ModuleReader.html#close--)
> method. Failure to close a module reader may result in a resource
> leak. The [`try-with-resources`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/tryResourceClose.html) statement provides a useful construct to
> ensure that module readers are closed.

----------

One  way to get the `Module` from the resources would be to access it using the [`Class#getModule`](http://download.java.net/java/jdk9/docs/api/java/lang/Class.html#getModule--) as:

    Module module = com.foo.bar.YourClass.class.getModule();

----------

***Edit***: I've learned with time a better way to use the `ModuleFinder` to access a `Module` as suggested by [@Alan](https://stackoverflow.com/a/46180598/1746118) as well could possibly be :

    ModuleFinder finder = ModuleFinder.of(path);
    ModuleLayer parent = ModuleLayer.boot();
    Configuration configuration = parent.configuration().resolve(finder, ModuleFinder.of(), Set.of("curious")); // 'curious' being the name of the module
    ClassLoader systemClassLoader = ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader();
    ModuleLayer layer = parent.defineModulesWithOneLoader(configuration, systemClassLoader);

    Module m = layer.findModule("curious").orElse(null);
answers.title: How to get a Module object from a ModuleReference
answers.body:
If you desire to access the module content you should open the ModuleReference that you've attained. This would provide you access to the ModuleReader which

is intended for cases where access to the resources in a module is required

A resource in a module is identified by an abstract name that is a '/'-separated path string. For example, module java.base may have a resource "java/lang/Object.class" that, by convention, is the class file for java.lang.Object. A module reader may treat directories in the module content as resources (whether it does or not is module reader specific). Where the module content contains a directory that can be located as a resource then its name ends with a slash ('/'). The directory can also be located with a name that drops the trailing slash.

Do keep in mind though, that the docs also specify :

A ModuleReader is open upon creation and is closed by invoking the close method. Failure to close a module reader may result in a resource leak. The try-with-resources statement provides a useful construct to ensure that module readers are closed.

One way to get the Module from the resources would be to access it using the Class#getModule as:

Module module = com.foo.bar.YourClass.class.getModule();

Edit: I've learned with time a better way to use the ModuleFinder to access a Module as suggested by @Alan as well could possibly be :

ModuleFinder finder = ModuleFinder.of(path);
ModuleLayer parent = ModuleLayer.boot();
Configuration configuration = parent.configuration().resolve(finder, ModuleFinder.of(), Set.of("curious")); // 'curious' being the name of the module
ClassLoader systemClassLoader = ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader();
ModuleLayer layer = parent.defineModulesWithOneLoader(configuration, systemClassLoader);

Module m = layer.findModule("curious").orElse(null);

answers.body_markdown: The classes in java.lang.module are more model world. Look at `java.lang.module.Configuration` and also `java.lang.ModuleLayer` to see how to create a configuration and instantiate it in the Java virtual machine as a layer of modules. There is a code fragment in the `ModuleLayer` javadoc that might get you going, just be warned that this is an advanced topic and best to master the basics first.
